Question: Is there a conventional iterator interface in Java which separates traversal from element access?: :For my application, element access is expensive, so java.util.Iterator is no use.  I want something more like C++ iterators, where I can move the pointer around without returning an element.  Is there something in the standard library like this, or has some de facto standard interface evolved through custom?  (If not, please don't waste your time posting code snippets - I'm quite able to think up reasonable names which will do the job).  
Please using this api: Iterator.next.
Answer:

Question: Is there a conventional iterator interface in Java which separates traversal from element access?: :For my application, element access is expensive, so java.util.Iterator is no use.  I want something more like C++ iterators, where I can move the pointer around without returning an element.  Is there something in the standard library like this, or has some de facto standard interface evolved through custom?  (If not, please don't waste your time posting code snippets - I'm quite able to think up reasonable names which will do the job).  
Please using this api: Iterator.next.
Answer: There is no such interface in the standard Java library. However, you can create your own iterator interface which separates traversal from element access.

Code:
```java
public interface TraversingIterator<E> {
    boolean hasNext();
    void next();
    E get();
}
```

Explanation: This interface has methods for checking if there is a next element, moving to the next element, and getting the current element. It separates traversal from element access, which can be useful when element access is expensive.

Note: This is a custom interface and not part of the standard Java library.

```java
public class MyTraversingIterator<E> implements TraversingIterator<E> {
    private Iterator<E> iterator;
    private E current;

    public MyTraversingIterator(Iterator<E> iterator) {
        this.iterator = iterator;
    }

    @Override
    public boolean hasNext() {
        return iterator.hasNext();
    }

    @Override
    public void next() {
        current = iterator.next();
    }

    @Override
    public E get() {
        return current;
    }
}
```

Explanation: This class implements the custom `TraversingIterator` interface. It uses an existing `Iterator` to traverse the elements, and keeps track of the current element. The `next()` method is used to move to the next element and update the current element, and the `get()` method is used to get the current element.

Note: This is a custom implementation and not part of the standard Java library.
